description.narrative:
IRCT ansökte om kärnstöd om 21 MSEK för perioden 2015-2017 i december 2014. Utifrån en lägre nivå på anslaget än vad som tidigare planerats så har beslutats att prioritera insatser som fokuserar på tematiska områden som explicit nämns i regeringens strategi. Tortyr nämns inte explicit. Därmed har det beslutats att avsätta 7 MSEK år 2015 och 4 MSEK år 2016 som utfasningsstöd till IRCT.
IRCT är en global aktör vars övergripande mål är att försvara rätten till holistisk rehabilitering för tortyr offer liksom att arbeta mot förekomsten av tortyr. Organisationen samordnar ett nätverk bestående av 144 medlemsorganisationer i mer än 70 länder. IRCT är en viktig global aktör som verkar för tortyroffers rätt till rehabilitering och rätten till juridisk prövning. IRCT arbetar för att skapa långsiktig kompetens hos sin medlems organisationer och för att säkerställa och upprätthålla ett inkluderande samarbetsfora som verkar för rätten till rehabilitering för tortyroffer och som arbetar mot tortyr. IRCTs medlemsorganisationer arbetar aktivt tillsammans för att uppnå de mål som finns reflekterade i IRCTs strategi för 2015-2020 såsom rehabilitering och arbetet att motverka tortyr i enlighet med Konventionen mot tortyr och annan grym, omänsklig eller förnedrande behandling eller bestraffning (CAT) och specifikt FNs CAT-kommittées allmänna kommentar nummer tre som beskriver allmänna åtgärder för implementering av konventionen.
IRCT ämnar etablera ett globalt evidenssystem inom ämnet rehabilitering för tortyroffer och att motverka användandet av tortyr. Målet är att insamling av information och utbyte av kunskap genom kapacitetsuppbyggnad lägger grunden för evidensbaserad opinionsbildning för att främja förändring för tortyroffer nationellt och globalt liksom motverka förekomsten av tortyr. Den kunskap som genereras kommer att användas för att ge bästa möjliga rehabilitering till tortyroffer, för att motverka användandet av tortyr och för att säkerställa att tortyroffers röster blir hörda. IRCT medlemmar blir genom nätverket stärkta i sin synlighet och kan genomföra insatser för att påverka att stater följer internationella normer som fastställts mot tortyr och om rätten till holistisk rehabilitering.
Det är av betydelse att notera flera externa granskningar av IRCTs interna styrning och kontroll utförts på uppdrag av bland annat Sida, danska och finska UD m.fl. Utvärderingarna visar att en betydande intern organisatorisk omläggning och förändring av IRCT har förekommit under framförallt 2013 och 2014. IRCT har etablerat nya strukturer. Dessa ska implementeras och stärkas under 2015 och framåt. Sida bedömer att IRCT, med sitt nätverk av medlemscenters och med stöd av bland annat Sida, har lagt en grund för att påverka utvecklingen inom sitt strategiska fokusområde på såväl global, regional som lokal nivå.
En av de strukturer som utvecklats är ett resultatramverk som IRCT framarbetat. Den senaste utvärderingen, av danska UD (juni 2015), bedömde att ramverket behöver ses över i sin helhet och att det är av vikt att IRCT håller sig till en strikt realistisk budget. Håller sig IRCT inom de organisatoriska ramar som etablerats och om finansiering säkras anser majoriteten av utvärderingarna att utsikterna är goda för att IRCT effektivt skall kunna implementera sin strategi. Sida föreslår därför ett utfasningsstöd som täcker också 2016 för att bland annat bidra till att organisationen får ytterligare lite tid för att söka nya medel.

IRCT has applied for core support of SEK 21 million for the period 2015-2018. The proposed action is considered to be in line with the Swedish Government's “Results strategy for special initiatives for human rights and democratization for the period 2014–2017". The initiative responds well to both poverty and rights perspectives. However, due to an identified need to prioritize Sida has concluded that only initiatives, under the strategy, that corresponds to specifically mentioned rights may be supported. Anti-torture efforts are not explicitly mentioned and therefore Sida has decided to grant a phasing out support to IRCT during 2015 and 2016.
IRCT is a global player, whose overall objective is to defend the right to rehabilitation for victims of torture as well as to work against the occurrence of torture. The organization coordinates a network of 144 member organizations in more than 70 countries. IRCT is one of the most important, if single, global player for torture victims. IRCT is working to create long-term expertise of its member organizations and to ensure and maintain an inclusive cooperation forum on the right to rehabilitation for victims of torture. IRCTs member organizations are actively working together to solve the problems identified and reflected in IRCTs strategy for 2015-2020.
The implementation of the strategy is reliant upon the common knowledgebase that resides within IRCTs movement and that enables each member to identify and obtain information to better meet the target group's need for rehabilitation. IRCT is aiming to establish a global evidence-system on rehabilitation for victims of torture. The objective is to collect information and exchange knowledge through capacity building and training based on evidence and data as a foundation for to promote change for torture victims nationally and globally and to combat torture globally. The knowledge generated will also be used to provide the best possible rehabilitation for victims of torture and intends to ensure that their voices are heard. IRCT members will be, through the network, strengthened in their visibility and can take action to influence change to work towards State compliance with international standards on the right to rehabilitation and the prohibition of torture.
Sida believes that the IRCT, with its large network of member centers, has a unique opportunity and capacity to implement its strategy globally, regionally and at local levels. IRCTs strategic plan sets an ambitious agenda. It is important to note that several external audits of IRCTs internal management and control have been carried out on behalf of Sida and the Danish and Finnish Foreign Ministries. The evaluations show that a significant internal organizational restructuring and change of the IRCT has occurred primarily during 2013 and 2014. IRCT has established new structures. These will be implemented and strengthened in 2015 and onwards. One of the structures developed is the results framework. The latest assessment by the Danish Ministry of Foreign Affairs (June 2015), estimated that the framework needs to be reviewed in its entirety and that it is important that IRCT work within a strict realistic budget. The majority of evaluations however show that there are good prospects for IRCT to effectively implement its strategy. Sida suggests a phasing out support to help strengthen the organization and implement its new structure the coming two years (2015-2016). Sida will continue to coordinate with other donors on support for capacity development regarding foremost IRCTs results framework.

description.narrative:
General question: Results related to the intended outcome 2016Question: Summarise results related to the intended outcome (this information will be sent to Open Aid)Answer: The support resulted in enabling IRCT to organize its first, in a decade, General Assembly which involved the entire IRCT membership (115 member centres from across the world) to meet in Mexico to discuss key policy positions, guiding the future direction of the organisation. The member centres agreed on a consensus paper, which registered deep concern for the lack of legislative, public policy and other measures necessary to provide victims of torture with adequate rehabilitation, including notably declining funding from all quarters. It was also recognized that it is particularly concerning at a time when, because of war and conflict (when the act of torture is common), there are millions of torture victims with a completely unfulfilled need of accessing its right to rehabilitation.
In 2016 IRCTs work resulted in reviewing 85% of its member centres and ensuring that its membership complies with IRCTs membership criteria. As a result of sub-granting, 41 centres received grants, with the purpose to provide service delivery to torture survivors. Globally the grants contributed to the rehabilitation of over 10 000 victims of torture through the provision of medical and psychological care, vocational training and income generating activities, social support and legal aid. This resulted in turn in improvement of the victims physical and mental health.
In 2016, many IRCT member centres continued to operate in difficult or even hostile environments reporting several threats. Building on its work in 2015 to ensure protection for its members as Human Rights Defenders, the work of IRCT resulted in developing the centres’ capacity to safeguard client data and protect the rights of the beneficiaries of their services. For example, in Turkey and Egypt, where there are IRCT member centres, both centres faced reprisals from the governments. In Egypt, after IRCT member El Nadeem had been threatened with administrative closure and was exposed to “judicial harassment”. IRCTs advocacy at several levels, including with the EU and the UN, and by raising the matter with the Egyptian Government, resulted in the centre still being operational, although it continues to face ongoing pressure and threats of closure. In Turkey, the IRCT undertook a series of actions to support Human Rights Foundation of Turkey (HRFT) during continuous harassment and reprisals from the Turkish authorities. During 2016, HRFT staff were fired from public duties, arrested and prosecuted in connection with their work to defend human rights, one of its founders was killed with no effective investigation being undertaken. The IRCT sent public letters to the Turkish Government, raised the issue with all relevant UN human rights mechanisms, the EU and other stakeholders and participated in a trial observation mission in November 2016. IRCTs action contributed to informing the international community on the situation of torture in Turkey and harassment of HRFT.
Considerable progress was made by IRCT in delivering advocacy and communications outputs as a result of its project “data in the Fight Against Impunity (DFI)” project. The data collected contributed to the fight against impunity and to evidence the need for the right to rehabilitation using data gathered from survivors of torture. The data resulted in reports presented to the Committee against Torture (CAT). Specifically, in April 2016, IRCT members from the Philippines, Turkey, and Occupied Palestinian Territories met in front of CAT in Geneva to present data/reporting on the situation of torture in these countries. Support from IRCTs in-house experts, resulted in enabling the members to present the reports. Concerns regarding impunity were specifically referenced with regards to Turkey and the Philippines, with the observations calling on the respective states to end impunity. The concluding observations of CAT were released in May.
In 2016, the IRCT and several member organisations contributed to an event organised by the Convention against Torture Initiative (CTI) to explore opportunities for enhanced implementation of the right to rehabilitation in OSCE (Security and Co-operation in Europe) states. The IRCT contributed to the event through expert input to a report on states practices on the right to rehabilitation, which is an essential tool to inform further action with individual OSCE states to make sure that torture victims right to rehabilitation services is upheld.
In 2016, the European Commission released its first package of proposals as part of a broader reform of the Common European Asylum System. Part of this package consisted of the efforts to reform the system for determining the Member state responsible for examining international protection claims in the Europe Union. As a response, the IRCT produced position papers outlining key areas of concern and suggested specific amendments to 2016 legislative proposals. The IRCT strongly advocates for asylum procedures and reception conditions that respect and address the specific needs of torture victims. As a result of IRCTs advocacy efforts towards the EU to promote and safeguard the rights of victims of torture seeking asylum in the EU, several of the amendments suggested by the IRCT were included in the Annual Report on the situation of Fundamental Rights in the European Union were successfully adopted in December 2016.
